head.title: Rags to Riches Will Probably Not Race Colts Again This Year

hedline.hl1: Rags to Riches Will Probably Not Race Colts Again This Year
hedline.hl2: Rags to Riches Will Probably Not Race Colts Again This Year

block.p: Although no firm plans have been made for the Belmont Stakes winner Rags to Riches beyond her next scheduled start, it appears she may not face colts in the Travers Stakes or at any time this year.

Her next appearance will be against fillies in the Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park on July 21. The Travers, run Aug. 25 at Saratoga Race Course, is perhaps the only race left this year that could feature a showdown among the three winners of the Triple Crown races. The Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense is definitely being pointed to the race.

The Travers, run Aug. 25 at Saratoga Race Course, is perhaps the only race left this year that could feature a showdown among the three winners of the Triple Crown races. The Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense is definitely being pointed to the race.

It is also a probable target for the Preakness winner Curlin, who will make his next start in the Haskell Invitational on Aug. 5 at Monmouth Park Race Track in Oceanport, N.J. Street Sense may also be entered in the Haskell.

Michael Tabor, the co-owner of Rags to Riches, who is trained by Todd Pletcher, would not rule out a start in the Travers. But Tabor said yesterday that it was more likely his filly would start in the Alabama Stakes at Saratoga against fillies on Aug. 18. The Alabama and the Travers are run at a distance of a mile and a quarter (10 furlongs).

''After the Coaching Club, the obvious choices are the Alabama and the Travers,'' Tabor said. ''At this moment in time, though, the Alabama is the favorite. She's already proven herself against the boys. She won the Belmont at a mile and a half, and the other two races are at a mile and a quarter. I'll leave the final decision up to Todd.
I know everybody would love to see her do it again, but, for me, she's already proven herself against the boys.''
Tabor, who said he planned to keep Rags to Riches racing next year, said his filly might run against colts in 2008 or even the next year.
''We plan to run her next year, and who's to say she won't run as a 5-year-old?'' Tabor said. ''We have all the time in the world to consider running her against the boys.''
Rags to Riches is undefeated this year in five starts, and she became the first filly to win the Belmont Stakes in 102 years.

The Green Monkey, who was sold last year as a 2-year-old for a world-record $16 million, worked three furlongs in 38.6 seconds Sunday at Belmont. Michael Tabor is a co-owner and Todd Pletcher is the trainer. The Green Monkey, who has been out with a muscle problem, had not had a published workout since October.
